description:
On September 7th, the new academic year started in Morocco. 
Schools are re-opening under a hybrid alternating model. Parents decide whether their children will be attending school online or in-person. For the children whose parents decided on in-person schooling, class time goes from the usual 30 hours a week to 15 hours a week, the other 15 hours to be completed at home under the supervision of their teachers.
Only students under 11 are allowed not to wear masks.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Morocco declares a state of sanitary emergency on March 20th.

On March 22nd, Morocco extends state of emergency until April 20.
 UPDATE: The original state of emergency declared on March 20th did not have a specified duration. On March 22nd it was extended until April 20th.
link: Coronavirus: Morocco Extends State of Emergency Until April 20

description: Morocco extends its state of sanitary emergency from April 20th to May 20th. UPDATE: Morocco has been consistently extending its state of emergency since it was declared on March 20th. This updates codes its extension from April 20th to May 20th.

Morocco extends its state of sanitary emergency from May 20th to June 10th. UPDATE: Morocco has been consistently extending its state of emergency since its declaration on March 20th. This update codes its extension from May 20th to June 10th.

Morocco extends the state of sanitary emergency from Wednesday, June 10, 2020, at six in the evening to Friday, July 10, 2020, at six in the evening. UPDATE: Morocco has been consistently extending its state of sanitary emergency ever since its declaration on March 20th. This update registers the extension from from Wednesday, June 10, 2020, at six in the evening to Friday, July 10, 2020, at six in the evening.

Morocco extends its state of sanitary emergency from July 10, 2020, at six in the evening to August 10, 2020, at six in the evening. UPDATE: Morocco has been consistently extending its state of sanitary emergency ever since its declaration on March 20th.
This update registers its extension from July 10th to August 10th.

Morocco extends its state of sanitary emergency from six in the evening on August 10th to six in the evening on September 10th. UPDATE: Morocco has been consistently extending its state of sanitary emergency ever since its declaration on March 20th.
This update registers its extension from six in the evening on August 10th to six in the evening on September 10th, 2020.

Morocco extends the state of sanitary emergency from September 10th to October 10th.
 UPDATE: Morocco has been consistently extending its state of sanitary emergency ever since its declaration on March 20th.
The latest decree extends it from September 10th to October 10th.

Morocco extends its state of sanitary emergency from six in the evening on October 10th to six in the evening on November 10th. UPDATE: Morocco has been consistently extending its state of sanitary emergency ever since its declaration on March 20th.
This update registers its extension from six in the evening on October 10th to six in the evening on November 10th, 2020.
On March 22nd, Morocco extends state of emergency until April 20.

Morocco extends its state of sanitary emergency from six in the evening on November 10th to six in the evening on December 10th. UPDATE: Morocco has been consistently extending its state of sanitary emergency ever since its declaration on March 20th. This update registers the extension from from November 10, 2020, at six in the evening to December 10, 2020, at six in the evening.

Morocco extends the state of sanitary emergency from December 10, 2020, at six in the evening to January 10, 2020, at six in the evening. UPDATE: Morocco has been consistently extending its state of sanitary emergency ever since its declaration on March 20th. This update registers the extension from from December 10, 2020, at six in the evening to January 10, 2020, at six in the evening.

Moroccan authorities conditionally open borders to foreign nationals as of September 7.  Those arriving in Morocco are required to present proof of a hotel reservation, a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken no more than 48 hours prior to arrival, and must not be subject to a visa formality. UPDATE: Moroccan authorities conditionally open borders to foreign nationals September 6.
target_geog_level: All countries

target_province: Casablanca-Settat; Marrakech-Safi; Fes-Meknes; Tanger-Ttouan-Al Houceima; Rabat-Sal-Kenitra; Oriental; Draa-Tafilalet; Bni Mellal-Khenifra; Souss-Massa; Laayoun-Sakia El Hamra; Dakhla-Oued Ed-Dahab; Guelmim-Oued Noun
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: Morocco extended lockdown from May 20, 2020 at six in the evening, until June 10, 2020 at six in the evening under the state of a health emergency.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Justice,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description:
On June 10th, Morocco started a careful lifting of the national lockdown, dividing the country into two areas. For the first area, only a few restrictions remain. For the second area, the lockdown remains as people still require a special license to leave their houses.
Area 2 comprises the following cities: Casablanca, Mohammedia, Rabat, Sal, Skhirate-Tmara, Tangier-Assilah, Marrakesh and Fs. But also the following provinces: Larache, El Hajeb, Kenitra, El Jadida, Nouaceur, Mediouna, Benslimane and Berrechid.
This entry codes the policy for the city of Tangier-Assila.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
On June 10th, Morocco started a careful lifting of the national lockdown, dividing the country into two areas. For the first area, only a few restrictions remain. For the second area, the lockdown remains as people still require a special license to leave their houses.
Area 2 now only comprises the following cities/provinces: Tangier-Asilah, Larache, Knitra and Marrakesh. 
This update codes the transition of Casablanca to the first area. UPDATE: Morocco started a careful lifting of the lockdown, dividing the country into two areas. For the first area, only a few restrictions remain. For the second area, the lockdown remains as people still require a special license to leave their houses.
In a second phase of the lifting of the lockdown, more cities and provinces have been added to the 1st area.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country

description: As of July 13th, family visits in prison are allowed to continue as normal. UPDATE: Originally, prisoners were allowed one visitor per month. As of July 13th, family visits are allowed to continue as normal.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
As of August 27th, Moroccan authorities are suspending family visits to prisons in select prisons around the country: 
"In Casablanca-Settat, the move will concern the prisons of Ain Sebaa 1, Ain Sebaa 2, the Ain Sebaa reform and rehabilitation center, and Ain Borja in Casablanca. In Rabat-Sale-Kenitra, the move will apply to Sale 2, El Arjat 1, El Arjat 2, and the local prison of Kenitra. Oudaya in Marrakech will also see suspended family visits, as well as Tangier 1, Tangier 2, and Tetouan in the region of Tangier-Tetouan-Al Hoceima, and Ras El Ma and Bourkaiz in Fez."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On September 8th, Morocco suspended visits to prisons.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On September 8th, Moroccan authorities suspended family visits to all prisons.
 UPDATE: The original policy only suspended visits in select prisons. As of September 8th, family visits are suspended in all prisons.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 11th, Morocco set up the Economic Watch Committee "to discuss and take the necessary measures to mitigate the economic and social impacts of the pandemic. It is chaired by the Minister of Economy, Finance and Administrative Reform and includes representatives from the public and private sectors."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Moroccan Embassy in China on Jan. 25 sets up a crises team and cell to follow the Covid-19 situation of the Moroccan community in China.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Moroccan authorities created local committees to control the application of COVID 19 prevention protocol in businesses, production factories, and commercial centers, the 22 June.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Moroccan King, on March 20th, order cities to launch public disinfection measures in public spaces (parks, streets and taxis).
type_text: Moroccan King, on March 20th, as part of the declaration of State of Emergency, order cities to launch public disinfection programs in public spaces (parks, streets and taxis).

description: After April 4th, Morocco discontinues the repatriation of deceased bodies into Moroccan territory from Moroccan citizens abroad, from all countries.
type_text: Morocco discontinued the repatriation of deceased bodies, which was a widely available service before this announcement was made.

description: On April 27th, the Moroccan government announced the delivery of financial aid to 4.3 million families working in the informal economy.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Moroccan embassy in Beijing provides Moroccan citizens in Hubei province with instructions to be repatriated or leave Hubei province.
type_text: The Moroccan embassy in China provides its citizens with a procedure to evacuate Hubei province.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Morocco orders the repatriation of 100 Moroccan nationals from the city of Wuhan on January 27.
type_text: Morocco's King, Mohammed VI, ordered the repatriation of 100 Moroccan nationals from the city of Wuhan.

description: Ivory Coast is receiving assistance from the Moroccan government. It includes eight million masks, 900,000 visors, 600,000 charlottes, 60,000 blouses, 300,000 litres of hydro-alcoholic gel, 75,000 boxes of chloroquine and 15,000 boxes of azithromycin. This on June 20th.
type_text: Morocco is providing aid to Ivory Coast.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: On January 29, the Moroccan Ministry of Health announces recommendations to avoid exposure to the virus: "wash their hands very often, cover their mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing and to avoid close contact with patients with symptoms of respiratory infection".
Starting January 30th, Morocco launches a new hotline called "Allo Yakada" to inform citizens about COVID-19.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 13th, the Moroccan Ministry of Islamic Affairs compelled imams all around the country to give a unified sermon on the dangers of COVID-19 and the precautions necessary to avoid it.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 16th the Moroccan Ministry of Health releases a digital health campaign to advise citizens on proper sanitation procedures for work spaces, homes and hospitals.

On October 16, mosques in Morocco are required to read a sermon in Friday prayer prepared by the Ministry of Islamic Affairs to justify and explain the reasoning behind the closing of mosques during the pandemic.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Morocco repatriated 167 Moroccan nationals from Wuhan and holds them in a military hospital for a 20-day quarantine. UPDATE: The original announcement was an order from King Mohammed VI for Moroccan nationals from Wuhan to be repatriated. On Feb 2, 167 Moroccan nationals were repatriated and held in quarantine in a military hospital for 20 days.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country

description: Morocco repatriated 167 Moroccan nationals from Wuhan and holds them in a military hospital for a 20-day quarantine.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country

description: The Moroccan government requests on March 2 that people who have traveled to a place where there is a Covid-19 outbreak stay away from public gathering places. They should self-monitor their temperature for 14 days and report to a health facility if they have any symptoms of the virus.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of March 13th, Moroccan authorities are imposing a 14-day quarantine on prisoners coming from abroad.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Morocco fixes measures regarding the passage to the second stage of the "Quarantine Mitigation Scheme" starting from June 24, 2020, at midnight:
- National level: reopening on-site cafes, restaurants, gyms, and public baths as well as commercial centers and malls without exceeding 50% of their capacity.
- Mitigation area n1: reopening beaches, outdoor sports spaces, and touristic institutions and activities with 50% of capacity. 
- Mitigation area n2: reopening barbershops and salons with 50% capacity.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Morocco fixes measures regarding the passage to the second stage of the "Quarantine Mitigation Scheme" starting from June 24, 2020, at midnight:
- National level: reopening on-site cafes, restaurants, gyms, and public baths as well as commercial centers and malls without exceeding 50% of their capacity.
- Mitigation area n1: reopening beaches, outdoor sports spaces, and touristic institutions and activities with 50% of capacity. 
- Mitigation area n2: reopening barbershops and salons with 50% capacity.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Transportation (land; water and air)") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of March 16th, Morocco is suspending court audiences except for the following cases: cases relating to remand, cases relating to the assignment of guardians to minors, urgent civil, commercial or administrative cases. Complaints are to be deposed online and detainees can only contact their lawyers through phone.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of March 16th, Morocco is suspending court audiences except for the following cases: cases relating to remand, cases relating to the assignment of guardians to minors, urgent civil, commercial or administrative cases. UPDATE: With the slow transition out of lockdown, detainees can meet with their lawyers in-person as of June 11th. Audiences remain suspended but will gradually incoporate more and more types of cases.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Moroccan committee tasked with preparing Morocco for a potential Covid-19 outbreak suggested the possibility of cancelling mass gatherings in a press release on Sunday, March 1.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Moroccan Fishing and Agriculture Ministry has cancelled the SIAM international agriculture trade fair due to the coronavirus emergency. UPDATE: Original government recommendation on March 1 was an indication that gatherings may be limited. This is the first instance on March 4 where a government event was cancelled to avoid mass gatherings.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Moroccan Ministry of Culture, Youth and Sports bans all events in which more than 1,000 people participate after March 5. UPDATE: The original declaration indicated the possibility of cancelling events, the restriction of gatherings with 1000+ people has been made official.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Moroccan Ministry of Endowments and Islamic Affairs announced on March 11 that it had decided to cancel all religious festivals, regardless of the size of gatherings, in the wake of the emerging epidemic of coronavirus in a number of countries.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Morocco is restricting public gatherings to 50 people after March 14, with the exception of businesses that follow official biosafety protocols published by the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Labor.
